entry.title: Why I Enjoy Blogging
entry.content:
See also: Alexâ€™s version of this blog post

I started this blog three years ago, moving from my older blog, hoping to written about programming, math, physics, books, and miscellenia. Iâ€™ve not quite written about everything I wanted to, but Iâ€™ve been very very happy with the experience of blogging. wc says Iâ€™ve written almost 75k words, which is mind-boggling to me!

I often get asked by others â€” usually trying to decide if they should start blogging â€” what itâ€™s like. I also often try to convince friends to blog by enumerating why I think itâ€™s awesome. Might as well write it down so that itâ€™s generally useful for everyone! ğŸ˜ƒ

Blogging helps cement my understanding of things!

Iâ€™ve often noticed that Iâ€™ll start blogging about something I think I understand, and it turns out that my understanding of the subject was somewhat nebulous. Turns out itâ€™s pretty easy to convince ourselves that we understand something.

The act of writing stuff down helps cement my own understanding â€” words are usually not as nebulous as thoughts so Iâ€™m forced to figure out little details.

I recall when I wrote my post on how Rustâ€™s thread safety guarantees work, I thought I understood Send and Sync in Rust. I understood what they did, but I didnâ€™t have a clear mental model for them. I obtained this mental model through the process of writing the post; to be able to explain it to others I had to first explain it to myself.

I point out this post in particular because this was both one of the first posts for me where Iâ€™d noticed this, and, more importantly, my more concrete mental model led to me finding a soundness bug in Rustâ€™s standard library. When I was thinking about my mental model I realized â€œan impl that looks like this should never existâ€, so I grepped the source code and found one1.

Iâ€™ve even noticed a difference between one-on-one explaining and explaining things through blog posts. I love explaining things one-on-one, itâ€™s much easier to tailor the explanation to the other personâ€™s background, as well as what theyâ€™re actually asking for help with. Plus, itâ€™s interactive. A lot of my posts are of the â€œokay I get this question a lot Iâ€™m going to write down the answer so I donâ€™t have to repeat myselfâ€ kind and Iâ€™ve found that Iâ€™ve often learned things from these despite having talked about the thing in the article contents multiple times.

I guess itâ€™s basically that blogging is inherently one-many â€” youâ€™re trying to explain to a whole group of people with varied backgrounds â€” which means you need to cover all your bases2 and explain everything together instead of the minimum necessary.

Itâ€™s really fun to revisit old posts!

Okay, Iâ€™ll admit that I never really write blog posts with this in mind. But when I do reread them, Iâ€™m usually quite thankful I wrote them!

Iâ€™m a fan of rereading in general, Iâ€™ve reread most of my favorite books tens of times; I make a yearly pilgrimage to James Mickensâ€™ website; I reread many of my favorite posts and articles on the internet; and I often reread my own posts from the past.

Sometimes Iâ€™ll do it because I want a refresher in a topic. Sometimes Iâ€™ll do it because Iâ€™m bored. Whatever the reason, itâ€™s always been a useful and fun thing to do.

Rereading old posts is a great way to transport myself back to my mindset from when I wrote the post. Itâ€™s easy to see progress in my understanding of things as well as in my writing. Itâ€™s interesting to note what I thought super important to include in the post then that I consider totally obvious now3. Itâ€™s interesting to relearn what Iâ€™ve forgotten. Itâ€™s reassuring to realize that my terrible jokes were just as terrible as they are now.

One of my favorite posts to reread is this really long one on generalized zero knowledge proofs. Itâ€™s the longest post Iâ€™ve written so far4, and itâ€™s on a topic I donâ€™t deal with often â€” cryptography. Not only does it help put me back in a mindset for thinking about cryptography, itâ€™s about something super interesting but also complicated enough that rereading the post is like learning it all over again.

It lets me exercise a different headspace!

I like programming a lot, but if programming was all I did, Iâ€™d get tired pretty quickly. When I was a student learning physics Iâ€™d often contribute to open source in my spare time, but now I write code full time so Iâ€™m less inclined to do it in my free time5.

But I still sometimes feel like doing programmery things in my spare time just â€¦ not programming.

Turns out that blogging doesnâ€™t tire me out the same way! Iâ€™m sure that if I spent the whole day writing Iâ€™d not want to write when I go home, but I donâ€™t spend the whole day writing, so itâ€™s all good. Itâ€™s refreshing to sit down to write a blog post and discover a fresh reserve of energy. Iâ€™m not sure if this is the right term, but I usually call this â€œusing a different headspaceâ€.

Iâ€™ve also started using this to plan my work, I mix up the kinds of headspace Iâ€™m employing for various tasks so that I feel energetic throughout the day.

This is also why I really enjoy mentoring â€” mentoring often requires the same effort from me as fixing it myself, but itâ€™s a different headspace Iâ€™m employing so itâ€™s less tiring.

Blogging lets me be lazy!

I often find myself explaining things often. I like helping folks and explaining things, but Iâ€™m also lazy6, so writing stuff down really makes stuff easy for me! If folks ask me a question I can give a quick answer and then go â€œif you want to learn more, Iâ€™ve written about it here!â€. If folks are asking a question a lot, thereâ€™s probably something missing in the documentation or learning materials about it. Some things can be fixed upstream in documentation, but other things â€” like â€œhow should I reason about modules in Rust?â€ deserve to be tackled as a separate problem and addressed with their own post.

(Yes, this post is in this category!)

Itâ€™s okay if folks have written about it before!

A common question Iâ€™ve gotten is â€œWell I can write about X but â€¦ there are a lot of other posts out there about it, should I still?â€

Yes!!

People think differently, people learn differently, and people come from different backgrounds. Existing posts may be useful for some folks but less useful for others.

My personal rule of thumb is that if it took me some effort to understand something after reading about it, thatâ€™s something worth writing about, so itâ€™s easier to understand for others like me encountering the subject.

One of my favorite bloggers, Julia Evans very often writes posts explaining computer concepts. Most of the times these have been explained before in other blog posts or manuals. But that doesnâ€™t matter â€” her posts are different, and theyâ€™re amazing. Theyâ€™re upbeat, fun to read, and often get me excited to learn more about things I knew about but never really looked at closely before.

I kinda feel itâ€™s my duty to?

Thereâ€™s a quote by Toni Morrison I quite enjoy:

I tell my students, â€˜When you get these jobs that you have been so brilliantly trained for, just remember that your real job is that if you are free, you need to free somebody else. If you have some power, then your job is to empower somebody else. This is not just a grab-bag candy game.

I enjoy it so much I concluded my talk at RustFest Kyiv with it!

I have the privilege of having time to do things like blogging and mentoring. Given that, I feel that it really is my duty to share what I know as much as possible; to help others attempting to tread the path Iâ€™m treading; and to battle against tribal knowledge.

When it comes to programming Iâ€™m mostly â€œself-taughtâ€. But when I say that, I really mean that I wasnâ€™t taught in a traditional way by other humans â€” I learned things by trying stuff out and reading what others had written. I didnâ€™t learn Rust by taking rustc and pretending to be a fuzzer and just trying random nonsense till stuff made sense, I went through the tutorial (and then started exploring by trying random stuff). I didnâ€™t figure out cool algorithms by discovering them from first principles, I picked them up from books and blog posts. Iâ€™m â€œself-taughtâ€ because Iâ€™ve been in charge of my learning process, but Iâ€™ve definitely relied on the work of other people throughout this process.

This means that for me, personally, knowledge-sharing is especially important. If I had to spend time figuring something out, I should make it easier for the next people to try7.

(All this said, I probably donâ€™t blog as much as I should)

You should blog too!

I wish everyone wrote more. I know not everyone has the time/privilege to do this, but if you do, I urge you to start!

I feel like tips on how to blog would fill up an entire other blog post, but Julia Evans has multiple posts on this that I strongly recommend. Feel free to ask me for review on posts!

As for the technicalities of setting up a blog, my colleague Emily recently wrote a great post about doing this with Jekyll. This blog uses Octopress which is similar to set up.
